verses.text: Now the Philistines gathered their armies for war. They assembled at Socoh, which belongs to Judah, and pitched camp between Socoh and Azekah, in Ephes-dammim.
verses.comment: Socoh and Azekah are towns in Judah—location detail preserved.

verses.text: Saul and the men of Israel gathered and camped in the Valley of Elah, and set their battle lines against the Philistines.
verses.comment: Valley of Elah: a key site for this confrontation.

verses.text: The Philistines were on one hill, and Israel was on another hill, with the valley between them.
verses.comment: Plain description of field positions; matches Hebrew structure.

verses.text: A champion named Goliath, from Gath, came out from the Philistine camp. His height was six cubits and a span.
verses.comment: 'Six cubits and a span' is approximately 9 feet 9 inches (about 3 meters).

verses.text: He had a bronze helmet on his head and wore coat of mail armor weighing five thousand shekels of bronze.
verses.comment: Five thousand shekels ~125 pounds (57 kg).

verses.text: He had bronze greaves on his legs and a bronze javelin slung between his shoulders.
verses.comment: Armor detail; 'greaves' refers to shin guards.

verses.text: The shaft of his spear was like a weaver’s beam, and its iron head weighed six hundred shekels. His shield-bearer walked ahead of him.
verses.comment: 600 shekels ~15 pounds (7 kg).

verses.text: Goliath stood and shouted to the Israelite battle lines, 'Why have you come out to set up in battle formation? Am I not a Philistine, and you servants of Saul? Choose a man for yourselves and let him come down to me.'
verses.comment: Speech adapted closely to Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: 'If he is able to fight with me and kill me, then we will become your servants. But if I prevail against him and kill him, then you will become our servants and serve us.'
verses.comment: Terms of battle stated plainly.

verses.text: And the Philistine said, 'I defy the battle lines of Israel today! Give me a man so we can fight together.'
verses.comment: ‘Defy’ translates Hebrew for ‘reproach’ or ‘challenge’.

verses.text: When Saul and all Israel heard these words of the Philistine, they were dismayed and very afraid.
verses.comment: ‘Greatly afraid’ rendered as ‘very afraid’ for modern clarity.

verses.text: Now David was the son of an Ephrathite of Bethlehem in Judah, named Jesse, who had eight sons. Jesse was old in Saul’s time and advanced in years among men.
verses.comment: David’s family background matches original text.

verses.text: Jesse’s three oldest sons had followed Saul to war: Eliab the firstborn, Abinadab the second, and Shammah the third.
verses.comment: Sons’ names as in previous chapter.

verses.text: David was the youngest. The three oldest followed Saul.
verses.comment: Short, literal statement.

verses.text: But David used to go back and forth from Saul to tend his father’s sheep at Bethlehem.
verses.comment: David had dual responsibilities.

verses.text: For forty days the Philistine came forward every morning and evening and took his stand.
verses.comment: Emphasizes ongoing challenge.

verses.text: Jesse said to his son David, 'Take for your brothers an ephah of this dried grain and these ten loaves, and bring them quickly to your brothers in the camp.'
verses.comment: Ephah is about 22 liters (or three-fifths of a bushel).

verses.text: 'And carry these ten cheeses to the commander of their thousand. See how your brothers are doing, and bring back news.'
verses.comment: Original uses ‘captain of their thousand’: military unit leader.

verses.text: Now Saul and they and all the men of Israel were in the Valley of Elah, fighting with the Philistines.
verses.comment: ‘Fighting’ may mean ‘waiting for battle’, but literal translation retained.

verses.text: David rose early in the morning, left the sheep with a keeper, took the supplies, and went as Jesse had commanded him. He reached the camp as the army was going out to the battle line, shouting the war cry.
verses.comment: Preserves action and order.

verses.text: Israel and the Philistines lined up for battle, army against army.
verses.comment: Reduces repetition; keeps literal phrasing.

verses.text: David left his things with the keeper of supplies, ran to the battle lines, and greeted his brothers.
verses.comment: Succinct, literal description.

verses.text: As he spoke with them, the champion, the Philistine from Gath named Goliath, came up from the battle lines and spoke the same words as before. David heard him.
verses.comment: ‘Same words’ - repetition noted as in Hebrew.

verses.text: All the men of Israel, when they saw the man, fled from him and were very afraid.
verses.comment: Repetition of fear reaction retained.

verses.text: The men of Israel said, 'Have you seen this man who has come up? Surely he has come up to defy Israel. Whoever kills him, the king will enrich with great riches, give him his daughter, and make his father’s house free in Israel.'
verses.comment: ‘Free’ means exempt from taxes and service.

verses.text: David spoke to the men standing by him, saying, 'What will be done for the man who kills this Philistine and takes away this disgrace from Israel? For who is this uncircumcised Philistine, that he should defy the armies of the living God?'
verses.comment: ‘Uncircumcised Philistine’ retained—emphasizes spiritual outsider.

verses.text: The people answered him in the same way, saying, 'So shall it be done for the man who kills him.'
verses.comment: Repetition as in original.

verses.text: When David’s oldest brother Eliab heard him talking to the men, Eliab’s anger burned against David, and he said, 'Why have you come down? And with whom have you left those few sheep in the wilderness? I know your pride and the evil in your heart; you have come to watch the battle.'
verses.comment: Eliab accuses David’s motives, as in Hebrew text.

verses.text: David said, 'What have I done now? Was it not just a word?'
verses.comment: David’s reply is ambiguous—Hebrew can be ‘Was it not just a question?’

verses.text: He turned away from him toward another and asked the same thing, and the people answered him as before.
verses.comment: Repetition is faithful to narrative rhythm.

verses.text: When David’s words were heard, they were reported to Saul, and he sent for him.
verses.comment: Clear, simple reporting as per text.

verses.text: David said to Saul, 'Let no man’s heart fail because of him; your servant will go and fight with this Philistine.'
verses.comment: Literal rendering preserved.

verses.text: Saul said to David, 'You are not able to go against this Philistine to fight him. You are just a youth, and he has been a warrior from his youth.'
verses.comment: Contrast of age and experience clearly stated.

verses.text: But David said to Saul, 'Your servant used to keep sheep for his father. When a lion or a bear came and took a sheep from the flock,'
verses.comment: Literally, ‘sheep from the flock’—matches original.

verses.text: 'I went after it and struck it and delivered the sheep from its mouth. When it turned against me, I seized it by its beard and struck and killed it.'
verses.comment: ‘Beard’—literal rendering.

verses.text: 'Your servant has killed both lion and bear, and this uncircumcised Philistine will be like one of them, because he has defied the armies of the living God.'
verses.comment: ‘Armies of the living God’ preserved as in Hebrew.

verses.text: David said, 'The LORD who rescued me from the paw of the lion and the paw of the bear will rescue me from the hand of this Philistine.' Saul said to David, 'Go, and may the LORD be with you.'
verses.comment: Saul’s words of blessing kept literal.

verses.text: Saul clothed David with his own armor. He put a bronze helmet on his head and dressed him in a coat of mail.
verses.comment: Saul’s personal armor given to David; literal phrase order.

verses.text: David fastened his sword over the armor and tried to walk, but he was not used to them. David said to Saul, 'I cannot go with these, for I am not used to them.' So David took them off.
verses.comment: ‘Not used to them’ for ‘not tested them’—clarifies meaning.

verses.text: He took his staff in his hand, chose five smooth stones from the brook, put them in the pouch of his shepherd’s bag, and had his sling in his hand. Then he approached the Philistine.
verses.comment: Literal rendering for items and actions.

verses.text: The Philistine walked closer to David, with his shield-bearer ahead of him.
verses.comment: Literal and clear.

verses.text: When the Philistine looked and saw David, he despised him, for David was only a youth, handsome and ruddy in appearance.
verses.comment: ‘Ruddy’ retained; means red-cheeked or fresh-faced.

verses.text: The Philistine said to David, 'Am I a dog, that you come at me with sticks?' And the Philistine cursed David by his gods.
verses.comment: Philistine blasphemy preserved as original.

verses.text: The Philistine said to David, 'Come here, and I will give your flesh to the birds of the air and the beasts of the field.'
verses.comment: Threat repeated later by David.

verses.text: Then David said to the Philistine, 'You come to me with a sword, spear, and javelin. But I come to you in the name of the LORD of hosts, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied.'
verses.comment: ‘LORD of hosts’ retained—standard OT title.

verses.text: 'This day the LORD will deliver you into my hand, and I will strike you down and cut off your head. I will give the bodies of the Philistine army this day to the birds of the air and to the wild animals of the earth; then all the world will know that there is a God in Israel.'
verses.comment: ‘Give bodies’—David expands the threat to all Philistines.

verses.text: 'And everyone gathered here will know that the LORD does not save with sword and spear. For the battle is the LORD’s, and he will give you into our hand.'
verses.comment: ‘The battle is the LORD’s’—theological point kept clear.

verses.text: When the Philistine arose and approached, David ran quickly toward the battle line to meet the Philistine.
verses.comment: David’s boldness emphasized.

verses.text: David put his hand in his bag, took out a stone, slung it, and struck the Philistine on his forehead. The stone sank into his forehead, and he fell facedown on the ground.
verses.comment: Literal description of Goliath’s defeat.

verses.text: So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and a stone. He struck the Philistine and killed him. There was no sword in David’s hand.
verses.comment: Emphasizes absence of sword, as in original.

verses.text: Then David ran and stood over the Philistine, took his sword, drew it out of its sheath, and killed him, and cut off his head with it. When the Philistines saw that their champion was dead, they fled.
verses.comment: David finishes Goliath with his own sword.

verses.text: The men of Israel and Judah rose up and shouted, and pursued the Philistines as far as Gath and the gates of Ekron. The wounded Philistines fell along the road to Shaaraim, as far as Gath and Ekron.
verses.comment: Geographical details retained.

verses.text: After chasing the Philistines, the Israelites returned and plundered their camp.
verses.comment: ‘Plundered’ accurately translates Hebrew for taking spoil.

verses.text: David took the Philistine’s head and brought it to Jerusalem, but he put his armor in his own tent.
verses.comment: At this time, Jerusalem is not yet an Israelite city.

verses.text: When Saul saw David going out against the Philistine, he asked Abner, the commander of the army, 'Abner, whose son is this youth?' Abner said, 'As surely as you live, O king, I do not know.'
verses.comment: Dialogue preserves formality of address.

verses.text: The king said, 'Find out whose son this young man is.'
verses.comment: Saul is interested in David’s family, matching Hebrew narrative.

verses.text: When David returned from striking down the Philistine, Abner brought him before Saul with the Philistine’s head in his hand.
verses.comment: David’s trophy prominently mentioned.

verses.text: Saul said to him, 'Whose son are you, young man?' David answered, 'I am the son of your servant Jesse the Bethlehemite.'
verses.comment: Shows David’s humility and family connection.
